descript.abstract: Regional Trails data set created by combining 31 different data sets and verified with orthophotography where applicable.
descript.purpose: Regional Trails to be published quarterly for RLIS Lite and provide trail information for various needs. This data set was created specifically for off-road trails and paths, though there are some regional connections that are on-street.
descript.supplinf: The schema was created by following the National Recreation & Park Association (NRPA) GIS Model for trails to set a standard among data providers.

idinfo.useconst: This database and GIS data are made available under the Open Database License (ODbL v1) and Database Content License (DbCL v1). See http://www.oregongmetro.gov/rlis-live.

horizpa.horizpar: Registered to tax lots. Street center lines were digitized from aerial orthophotography at +/- 10 feet accuracy. Tax lots were fit to the street centerlines. Beaverton, Oregon City and Tigard planning areas were improved to +/- 5 feet accuracy. Multnomah County was created with coordinate geometry using better control.

procstep.procdesc: Existing Trails: 31 Data sources provided a base to begin verifying alignment with aerial orthophotography. Attribute data was populated from these source layers. Where there was no attribute data provided, there was thorough research conducted to try and populate the records. Unknown values were used when there was no other information available.
Future Trails Added: The old RLIS regional planned trails data was incorporated into the new NRPA GIS database. Now all of the trails are maintained in the same database.

enttyp.enttypd: Attributes and descriptions associated with trails

attr.attrdef: Trail ID - Identification system to be created by Metro that will allow for linking to other GIS tables or related databases

Trail Name - Proper name of the trail or trail segment. No abbreviations. Access, connector, and spur trail names should use the same name as the main trail, appended with the appropriate suffix, e.g., Springwater Corridor - connector. Adjacent street names may be used for trail segments in road rights-of-way.
Trail System Name - Name of regional trail, major trail system, or park the trail or segment is a part of, e.g., Fanno Creek Greenway, Mountain Park Homeowners Association Trails, Forest Park.
Shared Name - Other name that the trail or trail segment is know by when the trail/segment is part of more than one route

Functional Class - Hierarchical classification by purpose and function. This represents a departure from classifying facilities by design. This functional classification hierarchy is analogous to a roadway classification system (interstate highways, arterials, collectors, local streets).

edom.edomvd: Also known as Community Connector Trails, these are typically much longer than Local trails though not as long as Regional trails. Community Trails link important land uses and areas of interest within a single jurisdiction. Examples are Tigard's Pathfinder-Genesis Trail, Portland's Columbia Blvd Trail, or Gresham's Butler Creek Greenway.

Sometimes called Local Access Trails or Neighborhood Trails, these provide connections to local features such as parks, community centers, and schools, and include most paths within parks, natural areas, planned developments, and campuses, as well as public stairways, alleys, and narrow ROWs.
Inter-state trails, e.g. Pacific Crest Trail or Columbia River Water Trail.
The Other value is reserved primarily for GIS trail features that don't necessarily exist on the ground but serve to connect trail segments to the GIS routable streets network.

Regional trails tend to be multi-jurisdictional, exceptionally long, and connect to regionally significant features such as Forest Park or the Tualatin River. Examples are the Gresham-Fairview Trail, Hillsdale to Lake Oswego Trail, or the Wildwood Trail.
Also known as Inter-regional Trails, State trails connect to destinations outside the region, e.g., Banks-Vernonia Trail or Willamette River Water Trail.
Unknown

attr.attrdef: City or Municipality - City or municipality that contains the trail, or trail segment, or main access point; Use proper city name or town; for long trails indicate the city/town near primary trail or trail segment access point; If trail segment occurs outside any city limits, then use Unincorporated
County - County where the majority of the trail or trail segment physically resides. Use proper county or parish name.
State - State or territory where the trail or trail segment exists. Use two character US postal code.
Status - Current physical state of the trail

edom.edomvd: Concept level alignments of trails not yet adopted in local plans, i.e., CIP, TSP, RTP, MTIP, and/or STIP.
Trail has been removed from service
Trail is open to the public, free of charge
Trail is open to the public, access fee is charged
Trail alignment is adopted in local plans, i.e., CIP, TSP, RTP, MTIP, and/or STIP.
Trail is open to the public, but access is restricted - ex by permit or reservation only
Trail exists but is privately owned and may not be open to the public
Status of the trail unknown

attr.attrdef: Length - Open for user to enter the length of the trail segment. Length units are in feet and are limited to two decimal places.
Trail Surface - The predominant surface type the user would expect to encounter on the trail

edom.edomvd: Shredded/chipped wood or bark
Boardwalks, recycled material etc.
Asphalt, concrete or similar
Imported aggregates, clay, gravel, crushed rock, shell, sand, etc
Existing earth
Other surface types including paver block, geo grid, etc
Snow (min coverage 75% of the snow season)
Water

attr.attrdef: Width - Average width range (e.g. 1-4, 5-9) of the trail or segment in feet. Do not include the trail shoulder. Future trails have null value.

edom.edomvd: Width of trail is 1-5 feet
Width of trail is 10-14 feet
Width of trail is 15 feet or greater
Width of trail is 6-9 feet
Width of trail is unknown

attr.attrdef: Accessibility Status - Accessibility guideline compliance status for trail or segment that are designed for pedestrian use

edom.edomvd: Trail meets current accessibility guidelines (ADA and Access Board Interpretation/Guidelines)
Trail determined ineligible to meet current trail accessibility guidelines
Trail does not meet accessibility guidelines
Trail not evaluated for accessibility

attr.attrdef: Mode: Pedestrian - Hiking, walking, running modes of travel are permitted and appropriate considering the design, character and management of the trail segment

edom.edomvd: Not designed for pedestrian use
Not permitted
Permitted

attr.attrdef: Mode: Road Bike - Bicycling modes of travel are permitted and appropriate considering the design, character and management of the trail segment. (Could include electric bike or Segway type transport)

edom.edomvd: Not designed for road bikes, i.e., not paved.
Not permitted
Permitted

attr.attrdef: Mode: Mountain Bike - Mountain bicycle modes of travel are permitted and appropriate considering the design, character and management of the trail segment

edom.edomvd: Not designed for mountain bikes, i.e., paved.
Not permitted
Permitted

attr.attrdef: Mode: Equestrian - Equestrian, pack & saddle modes of travel are permitted and appropriate considering the design, character and management of the trail segment

edom.edomvd: Not designed for horses, i.e., paved and/or too narrow.
Not permitted
Permitted

attr.attrdef: Mode: Motorized Watercraft - Non-motorized watercraft are permitted and appropriate considering the design, character and management of the trail segment

edom.edomvd: Not water
Not permitted
Permitted

attr.attrdef: On Street Bike - Designated route or portion of street for bike usage. Bikes in bike lanes or shared roadway.

edom.edomvd: Mode: Road Bike equals N/A or No. Includes segments that are not designed for or do not allow bikes.

Bikes use a separated facility, either within road right of way, or in separate right of way. This includes two-way paths at least 8 feet wide running parallel to streets in the same right of way, a.k.a., sidepaths. Separation between bikes and car travel lanes should include grade separation, such as curbs, and a planting strip.

Bikes share the street or road with cars. Not limited to public right-of-way. This could include several facility types, including bike lanes, bike boulevards, shared roadways, sharrows, signed connections, or cycletracks. Does not include sidewalks or sidepaths that are shared with pedestrians.

attr.attrdef: Managing Agency - Organization with legal right to control or regulate the access to and use of the trail
Agency Type - Type of managing organization

edom.edomvd: Managed by county government or agency
Managed by federal government or agency
Managed by municipal government or agency
Managed by a special park district, e.g., THPRD
Managed by a special park district, e.g., THPRD
Managed by a private home owner association
Trail managed by private non-profit organization, for example a land trust, conservancy, etc
Managed by a private individual, business or commercial entity
Managed by a school district
Managed by a special district government, e.g., Metro, Clean Water Services
Managed by state government or agency
Managing agency unknown

enttyp.enttypd: Attributes and descriptions associated with trails

attr.attrdef: Non-RLIS - Source where the data layer originated
Non-RLIS - Park Trail - Trails/paths internal to parks or natural areas usually for visitor circulation or experience

edom.edomvd: Trail is not within a park or natural area. Typically, this includes trails in public right-of-way, trails on campuses, trails in planned developments, and trails along corridors, such as rail-trails, levee trails, freeway trails, etc.

Part of an internal trail system within a public or private park or natural area. Does not include linear trail corridors that are outside a park or natural area, even if the trail is managed by a park agency.

attr.attrdef: Used for querying trails segments for bike network

edom.edomvd: Do not include segment in bike network
Do not include segment in bike network, even if the segment has all other flags consistent from standard to include query
Include segment in bike network
Include segment in bike network, even if the segment has other flags inconsistent from standard to include query

attr.attrdef: Non-RLIS - Year Opened - Year the trail was made available for public use (YYYY)
Non-RLIS - Difficulty Rating - Relative difficulty rating of the trail or trail segment

edom.edomvd: A trail requiring limited skill with little challenge to travel - mostly level; adequate width; minor crossings, well marked
A trail requiring some skill and challenge to travel. Minor ascent/descent; narrow passages; heights; natural crossings; length
A trail requiring a high degree of skill and challenge to travel. Significant ascent/descents; scrambling crossings; some bouldering, extensive length from trail head to trail access
Rapids above level 2 for canoes or 3 for Kayaks, climbing gear, cold weather gear suggested
Difficulty depends on environmental conditions, floods, ice, snow etc.

distinfo.distliab: The information in this file was derived from digital databases on Metro's GIS. Care was taken in the creation of this file. Metro cannot accept any responsibility for errors, omissions, or positional accuracy. There are no warranties, expressed or implied.

onlinopt.accinstr: Email drc@oregonmetro.gov or call 503-797-1742 for further instructions.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
